title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
A rout in tech stocks deepened Friday, bringing the Nasdaq's losses for April to more than 13%, the index's worst monthly performance in more than a decade. The S&P 500 and Dow dropped 8.8% and 4.9%, respectively, in April.

---

Compensation for U.S. workers grew rapidly in the first quarter, as a tight labor market put more money in their pockets while also keeping pressure on inflation.

Consumers spent more in March, showing that U.S. households are absorbing high inflation.

---

China is preparing to hit pause on its monthslong campaign against tech companies, according to people familiar with the matter.

---

Couche-Tard and EG Group are in talks about a deal. A combination of the convenience-store companies would have over $70 billion in annual revenue.

---

Exxon's first-quarter profit more than doubled to $5.5 billion, while Chevron earned $6.3 billion, up from about $1.4 billion in the year-earlier period.

---

The EPA issued an emergency waiver to allow gas stations to sell high-ethanol content gasoline this summer, fulfilling a directive from Biden.
